awd_titl_txt: Creating and Using Social Impact Models for Engineered Products
awd_abstract_narration:
Every product has economic, environmental, and social impacts on those who produce and use it. While environmental and economic impacts are relatively well known and appropriate measures have been identified and implemented, very little work has been done to help guide engineers, understanding of social impacts. Therefore, this project focuses on creating ways to measure and evaluate the social impacts of engineered products. Accordingly, the research questions pursued in this project are: (i) How are social impacts of products influenced by engineering decisions, (ii) What studies can be carried out to evaluate the social impact of existing products? (iii) What are social impacts as they relate to engineering decisions that can be observed in existing products? (iv) What is an appropriate framework to guide engineers "understanding of anticipated social impacts of products they're designing" This research promises to improve industrial competitiveness by enabling engineers to account for social factors that oftentimes dictate the success of engineered products, but currently are difficult for engineers to consider formally. It also will promote a vision of sustainable design and engineering in which needs of the present are met without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. Thus, this research intends to have a broad impact on industry and society by transforming how the social impact of engineered products can be understood, predicted and considered in the design and optimization of engineered products. 

This research will be carried out by, first, defining the boundaries of social impact. This part of the research tames the unwieldy concept of social impact and frames it in a way that links it to engineering decisions, making it tangible to engineers and laying the foundation for future research in sustainable design and engineering. Second, this research will execute empirical studies to model the social impact of existing products. This area of focus involves examining a variety of products/projects with industrial collaborators all over the world who have agreed to provide us with access to existing product and project data. These collaborators bring insight ranging from medical products to consumer products to humanitarian projects and they will provide data and insight from North America, South America, Europe, Africa, and Asia. Third, this research will extract principles from the empirical studies that act as a foundation for developing a framework for engineers to improve social impacts of their products. Key principles will be extracted and articulated after observing the social impact modeling patterns in the empirical studies. These principles will be at the foundation of the modeling framework created. Fourth, the research will create a principles-based framework to guide engineers in developing social impact models--deterministic and non-deterministic. This portion of the research seeks to develop a generic framework for identifying a product?s social impacts, converging on one or more social sustainability measures for the product, and linking those measures to the engineer-controlled parameters of the design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Engineered products, machines, and systems affect society. Sometimes the effect is obvious such as when a bridge is built across a body of water to connect two societies. Other times, however, the social impacts are less obvious such as how the presence of the bridge positively and negatively affects the two neighborhoods where the bridge comes aground, or how the tolling structure of the bridge inadvertently excludes segments of society that can't afford the tolls.

Generally speaking, engineering practice and the engineering literature focus on engineering methodologies for designing products, machines, and/or systems that provide obvious benefit to society by filling a need or solving a problem. While so doing, the engineer's standard -- but limited -- practice is to ensure that the engineered products are safe in terms of bodily harm to people.

The outcome of this research project is a substantially expanded theory for considering and designing the social impact of engineered products. Working in an interdisciplinary team involving mechanical, manufacturing, and systems engineers, as well as social scientists and business strategists, 11 areas of social impact for engineered products were identified as part of this project. That is to say, the way engineered products can positively and negatively impact society are now articulated into 11 categories as a result of the research. Just as engineers are trained to check the safety of the products they design, the results of this research project facilitate the engineers' ability to check 10 additional impact areas as part of their design effort.

Including the traditional impacts on health and safety, the 11 areas of social impact for engineered products are:

1. Impacts on Health and Safety
2. Impacts on Paid Work
3. Impacts on Stratification
4. Impacts on Human Rights
5. Impacts on Education
6. Impacts on Family
7. Impacts on Gender
8. Impacts on Population Change
9. Impacts on Conflict and Crime
10.  Impacts on Networks and Communication
11.  Impacts on Cultural Identity and Heritage

Resulting from this research project are various tools and mechanisms for integrating awareness of these social impact areas into engineering practice. These tools and mechanisms range from a simple list of 55 Social Impact Consideration Questions, such as "In what ways could the product move behaviors away from traditional practices?", to predictive modeling methods of various complexity, to agent-based life cycle analysis simulations. All of which lent insight into dealing with the broad societal impacts of engineered products.

The creation and development of such tools were supported by numerous experiments including the evaluation of 150 existing products designed for social impact, interviewing more than 50 professionals regarding their company's practices for social impact evaluation, and a deep evaluation of the literature. It also involved multiple experiments with design teams, learnings from actual design projects, and various computational studies.

Like many research projects, this project has opened the door to various other studies that could be conducted and that could lead to a future where engineered products are designed with deep consideration and explicit evaluation of all 11 social impact categories listed above, whereas at present they are only deeply evaluated relative to impacts on health and safety. Importantly, such consideration and evaluation is just one of the three pillars of sustainability, which are social sustainability, environmental sustainability, and economic sustainability. This research project has made substantial headway in social sustainability.
